Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Role of Bristled Wings for Flying and Swimming at Low Reynolds Numbers

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512071(Santhanakrishnan) & 1511427(Miller)

The focus of the proposed project is to explore the fluid dynamic principles that enable small insects to generate lift and produce thrust. When the wings of small insects clap together during the flapping motion and then fling apart, there is the expectation that flight would not be efficient, but it is. Resolving this paradox can have a significant scientific and technological impact, because we could also design machinery that takes advantage of such phenomena like small robotic vehicles that move across fluid-air interfaces.

The proposal is focused on the understanding of the phenomena involved when bristled wings, like those of small insects generate lift. Although the aerodynamic principles of insect flight at the scale of fruit flies and above are reasonably well understood, the fluid dynamic mechanisms that enable very tiny insects to generate lift or thrust remain unclear. When the wings clap together at the end of the upstroke of the flapping motion and fling apart at the start of the downstroke, there are novel phenomena that take place. The fundamental investigation in this work will be focused on a particularly intriguing paradox: why is there a noted biological preference in almost all tiny insects to employ interacting bristled wings under highly viscous conditions that would require large forces to peel the wings apart? It is proposed to develop 3D poroelastic models to study locomotion using bristled appendages. Two types of insects will be examined (thrips and parasitoid wasps), which are capable of flying in air and swimming in water. The experiments in this proposal will also use robotic wing-wing interaction platforms with dynamically scaled bristled wing models informed by high-speed videos of tiny insects. Wing design and kinematics for flapping propulsion at low Re will be identified through numerical simulations of experimentally validated poroelastic wing models implemented in an immersed boundary method framework. Graduate and undergraduate student involvement in the research is proposed. Minority student participation will be pursued through the Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program at both institutions. Outreach activities for high school students and teachers participating in the Oklahoma State University National Lab Day annual event are also described.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insects that fly or swim with body lengths under 1 mm, roughly the size of a sand grain, show two distinctive physical adaptations of bristled/hairy wings and flapping motion where wings ‘clap’ together at the end of moving upward and ‘fling’ apart when the wings start to move downward. Although the fundamental principles underlying the flight of larger insects are reasonably well understood, the physical mechanisms that enable tiny insects such as thrips to remain aloft and migrate large distances remain unclear. Tiny insects also serve as an ideal model system to guide the development of miniaturized aerial and underwater drones. From experiments on artificial wing models driven by a flapping robot, we find that inclusion of bristles can significantly lower the amount of resistance experienced during ‘clap and fling’ motion. This lowered resistance to wing motion is enabled by partial leakage of flow through the gaps between the bristles. Our studies show that ‘clap and fling’ is particularly well-suited to tiny insect flight as opposed to the flight of larger insects such as fruit flies that are rarely observed to use this type of flapping motion. The area occupied by the bristles relative to the wing area was found to be in a narrow range in thrips, and experimental tests show that bristled wings designed in this range provide improved aerodynamic efficiency. With increasing the angle of bristled wing rotation relative to the vertical, we find that resistance to motion decreases. This may explain why tiny insects are observed to use large rotational angles in fling. When testing models varying the number of bristles within the broad range observed in tiny insects, we find that flight performance is nearly unaffected. This suggests that biological bristled wings are fairly robust in delivering adequate aerodynamic performance and the number of bristles need not be optimized to fall in a narrow range. This award has provided opportunities for several graduate and undergraduate students to receive cross-disciplinary training in techniques used in engineering design and manufacturing, fluid mechanics, aerodynamics, and biomechanics. An inexpensive, hands-on ‘build a tiny bug’ activity was developed for groups of high school students and teachers visiting Oklahoma State University for the annual National Lab Day event. This activity provided the students and teachers a first-hand opportunity to experience how engineering approaches can be used to study biological questions and in biologically inspired design of devices.
